content.title: Small Saphenous Vein Anatomy
content.definition: The superficial vein of the posterior calf extending from the lateral malleolus to the saphenopopliteal junction, draining the lateral and posterior lower leg.

concepts.definition: The anatomic pathway of the small saphenous vein.

clinical_features.origin: Posterior to lateral malleolus, lateral marginal vein
clinical_features.calf: Ascends in posterior midline of calf between gastrocnemius heads
clinical_features.termination: Variable - typically saphenopopliteal junction in popliteal fossa
clinical_features.position: Lies within subfascial compartment in majority of cases

clinical_features.typical: Joins popliteal vein at or below popliteal crease
clinical_features.giacomini_extension: Thigh extension connecting to GSV or deep veins
clinical_features.absent_spj: May drain entirely via perforators in some patients

clinical_features.relationship: Sural nerve runs adjacent to SSV in posterior calf
clinical_features.surgical_risk: High risk of nerve injury during stripping
clinical_features.clinical_significance: Contributes to preference for endovenous ablation

concepts.definition: Branches of the small saphenous vein.

clinical_features.ultrasound_mapping: Essential before intervention due to anatomic variability
clinical_features.ablation_considerations: Avoid proximal treatment near popliteal vein junction

sources.reference: Caggiati A et al. J Vasc Surg. 2002;36:416-422
Delis KT et al. J Vasc Surg. 2004;39:1284-1289
